title: 107_s2710
content: The Act titled "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. Qualified employee health insurance expenses refer to amounts paid by an employer for coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'qualified employee' refers to any employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those covered under salary reduction arrangements. The definition of 'health insurance coverage' is based on section 9832(b), disregarding the last sentence of paragraph (2). The credit for employee health insurance expenses is part of the general business credit, with no carrybacks allowed before effective date. No portion of the unused business credit for any taxable year attributable to the employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G can be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2003. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses incurred after December 31, 2002, for coverage established post-enactment of the Act.
